hl1: Cell samples to go
hl2: Boston firm finds new homes for unused materials from research labs
lede: kerafast helps research teams find biologic materials they need, like the cell culture at right. chinchilla tissue samples millions of tiny tubes of cells, proteins, antibodies, and other scientific goo sit in freezers at research institutions across the country. these leftovers of past lab experiments can languish for years, frozen and forgotten. now a boston company called kerafast inc. is helping institutions clean out their freezers and reuse biological materials for new research through an online marketplace, a sort of craigslist for biologists. since kerafast began its service in 2010, more than 2,000 researchers around the world have used the company's website to search the freezers of 112 research institutions, buying unique biologic materials created in experiments by other scientists.
body: annie huhn, a research fellow at dana-farber cancer institute, recently spent $250 for a line of cells on kerafast that helped her with her work studying proteins. "they have materials that you're definitely not going to find anywhere else," huhn said. robert p. bondaryk, a biochemist by training and veteran of the biotech industry, hatched the idea for kerafast six years ago. "this is gold in freezers that many institutions are sitting on," said bondaryk, the company's chief executive. "let's take what's in their freezers and make money from it." a year after its launching, kerafast had signed up 10 institutions. this summer, the company hit a milestone when it enrolled its 100th research institution, adding to a list that includes boston children's hospital, massachusetts institute of technology, the university of massachusetts, and harvard university. most of the biologic concoctions kerafast sells look like clear liquids to the naked eye. but scientists see much more: raw materials for research that could lay the groundwork for discoveries of life-changing drugs to treat cancer, alzheimer's, and many other debilitating diseases. the products offered on kerafast's website are divided into different research areas, such as cancer, stem cells, immunology, and neurobiology. click on cancer, and you get a list of dozens of "featured products" — myriad varieties of cells, antibodies, and more —for sale. each item comes with a short description that includes the name of the scientist who created it. prices range from $65 to more than $6,000 per product. the average order is about $500. kerafast ships the products quickly, packed in dry ice, from one lab to another, sometimes around the world. thomas fazzio, assistant professor of molecular medicine at umass medical school in worcester, needed a certain type of antibody, a protein the immune system produces to fight harmful substances, for his work with stem cells. he contacted a lab in california, but did not hear back for weeks. he did not want to try developing the antibodies on his own, because the process would have taken months and cost thousands of dollars. a google search led fazzio to the kerafast website, where he found the material he needed for about $300. "we can buy it one day and get it the next day, as opposed to begging somebody else for it," fazzio said. kerafast splits its sales revenues with the research institutions that supply its inventory. bondaryk initially established the company as a nonprofit, with a mission to provide a new source of revenue for institutions at a time when federal support for research was waning. but he switched to a for-profit model because it allows kerafast to charge more for products and allow research institutions and the company to earn more. kerafast handles all the administrative work required to sell its products, including the legal agreements, which are necessary because the biologic materials are considered intellectual property. this is helpful especially f or smaller research institutions, such as brandeis university in waltham, where staff do not have the time or resources to seek out new homes for their surplus materials. "we're a really small tech-transfer office. i don't want to get bogged down in red tape," said rebecca menapace, associate provost at brandeis. bondaryk estimates there are as many as 1 billion tubes of bioresearch materials sitting in freezers across the united states. every day, he tries to add a few more of these materials to his website, where scientists can access them. "our approach is to take any material and try it out," bondaryk said. "the downside is maybe something doesn't sell, but the upside is you discover stuff you never thought anyone would want." cells for sale the kerafast website featured these "new additions" tuesday: priyanka dayal mccluskey can be reached at priyanka.mccluskey @globe.com.

hl1: TOWN CLEARED OF HARASSMENT CHARGE
author: JOHANNA SELTZ
lede: cohasset a norfolk superior court jury has cleared the town of sexual harassment charges made by a former police dispatcher.
body: barbara dewolfe worked for the town for about a year and a half before she was fired in october 2003 for chronic lateness and overuse of sick time, according to the town's attorney, leonard kesten. she filed a civil lawsuit six months later claiming she was the victim of a sexually hostile work environment, and that a sergeant inappropriately touched her and circulated naked pictures of himself. the case came to trial this month. "the sergeant, who retired after 29 years, was at the trial the whole week and he was fully vindicated," kesten said. de wolfe's attorney, james ciapciak of norwood, said he will appeal.

hl1: A BRUTAL REMINDER OF GENOCIDE IN RWANDA
author: By Matthew Gilbert Globe Staff
lede: why make movies about history's most epic failures of humanity, reducing them to some 120 minutes of melodrama, suspense, and tear-jerking? the question has haunted so many holocaust films, with their portrayals of ez-to-read heroism set against heart-rending strains of klezmer.    hbo's rwanda-set "sometimes in april" clearly articulates the best answer after its final credits, with the simple phrase "never forget." translating the horrors of genocide into fictional stories is a way of embedding them in our cultural memory. about the 1994 murder of some 800,000 tutsis and moderate hutus in rwanda, "sometimes in april" stands as an important remembrance, a cinematic antidote to the denial that comes with time and ignorance. the movie, which premieres tomorrow night at 9, is a brutal, depressing, dramatically flawed, but essential reminder.
body: april is the start of the rainy season in rwanda, and it is also the month that hutu extremists began their calculated slaughter in 1994. as bullets begin to rain down on terrified families, the african nation fell into a hell virtually ignored by the rest of the world. the panoramic "sometimes in april" tries to capture the 100 days of murder and rape from all points of view, including rwandans living deep within the bloody conflict and a well-meaning american bureaucrat (debra winger's deputy assistant secretary of state) who's helpless amid washington indifference. ambitiously, the movie aims to encompass the personal and the political angles. but its strongest material is its intimately told personal story, about two rwandan brothers on different sides of the battle.    augustin (idris elba) is a peaceful hutu army general married to a tutsi woman, jeanne (carole karemera). as april 1994 dawns, he desperately tries to move her and their three children to safety, since they've become walking targets. honore (oris erhuero), on the other hand, is an incendiary dj on a hate radio station who provokes hutu listeners to kill their tutsi neighbors, commonly referred to as "roaches." in the atmosphere of growing chaos, honore's broadcasts provide an important unifying and informational tool to the loose army of genocidal killers.    too obviously, honore is meant to be symbolically responsible for the sad fate of augustin's family. but the gentle dialogue from writer-director raoul peck, and the soulful performances by elba and erhuero, nicely muddy the moral waters. elba, from "the wire," is particularly impressive here, as he bears the emotional weight of the movie on his still face.    the action toggles between 1994 and 2004, when honore is standing trial at the united nations tribunal in tanzania. he is pleading guilty to war crimes, and clearing his conscience, and so he invites augustin to come visit him in prison. still grieving over his losses, unable to move forward with his life, augustin reticently takes up his estranged brother's invitation. together again across a prison table, they define a decade of disaster and pain.    ultimately, "sometimes in april" succumbs to schematic plotting. having brothers representing two sides of a coin is convenient enough; adding in a few more heavily emblematic relationships strains the believability of the fictional story. the identity of augustin's girlfriend, which i won't reveal here, is one of the twists that seems unnecessarily contrived. in an atmosphere of messy street violence and anarchy, the movie's story line is too neat.    and peck's portrait of the lack of us intervention comes off as simplistic. whether his take bears truth isn't the issue; it's the cursory way he mixes it into his fiction with a handful of news clips and scenes of winger's character fretting. how the un dealt with or didn't deal with the rwandan genocide is a movie of its own, and not just the peripheral drama in an otherwise powerful tale.     matthew gilbert can be reached at gilbert@globe.com.

hl1: Blind date: Two to tango
hl2: Will these daters be in synch or out of step?
lede: go on a blind date. we'll pick up the tab. fill out an application at bostonglobe.com/cupid. joanna mcpherson 21 / student her perfect saturday wake up early, go for a walk, meet my friends for good food, go to a concert or festival, dance, and end the night talking and laughing
body: body who would play her in a movie? a taller amanda seyfried saatvik ahluwalia 24 / marketing communications associate what makes him a catch i'm tall, dark, and handsome (though i suppose that is subjective). i'm also a phenomenal dancer. what comedian's sense of humor mirrors his? aziz ansari or jon stewart, depending on my mood 7 p.m. besito mexican, burlington > shall we dance? saatvik the only thing i really did to prepare for the date was shave. joanna i got my dress preapproved by a friend. saatvik i was excited. never been on a blind date, and i like meeting new people, so didn't really feel nervous. joanna i was definitely nervous, but i figured if the person also signed up to do this, then they were likely to be pretty outgoing and interesting. > you lead, i'll follow saatvik i got there about 10 minutes early, so i just asked them to seat me. joanna the waitress walked me over to him. we shook hands and introduced ourselves. saatvik joanna was quite beautiful. what you'd imagine a girl from scandinavia would look like: tall, blond, blue eyes. joanna i thought that he was handsome and was wearing a nice blazer. saatvik i think we both felt very comfortable from the start. the conversation flowed well, and we were laughing most of the time. it went really well overall. joanna we joked about starting to salsa dance in the restaurant after discussing the many dance styles he knows, but no salsa dancing ended up happening. saatvik i found her attractive when i first saw her, but i suppose seeing her personality did make her seem more attractive. joanna we traded stories about getting in trouble in high school and how our parents had both reacted the same way. our dads had laughed at their "nerdy" children getting into trouble. saatvik the whole evening just went really well, and i felt that we had great chemistry. > the big dip joanna he suggested that we get dessert and a drink at the cheesecake factory, so we walked over there and sat outside. i was happy to continue the date. we were having a nice time, and i enjoy cheesecake. saatvik the night ended with me walking joanna to her car. joanna i told him it was an embarrassingly colored bright blue car, and he joked that it matched my eyes. we hugged good night, and i gave him my number. > second date? joanna we've already texted about hanging out again. saatvik i think we might see each other again before she leaves for college. just depends how things turn out.   > post-mortem saatvik a joanna a go on a blind date. we'll pick up the tab. fill out an application at bostonglobe.com/cupid.

hl1: Sutter's options stay open;
lede: brian sutter was fielding calls yesterday at his home in andover, but the former bruins coach didn't sound as if he would be signing on soon with another national hockey league club. "you know, i really don't want to get into it," he said when asked about reports that he is a candidate to replace dave king behind the calgary flames' bench. "teams have called, and that's all i want to say. we're planning on going home for the summer right now, that's all. put it this way: we're not jumping into anything unless it's great."
body: sutter returns to sylvan lake, alberta, each summer, not far north of calgary. dismissed after the bruins lost in the first round of the playoffs to new jersey, he has spent the last few days packing up his household goods and readying for the trip west. "three years ago, before we took the job here, the flames had some interest in us," said sutter.  "we've had friends calling us from back there because it's been in the papers, i guess, but we haven't had any discussions. if they want to talk, they know where we're at." islander general manager don maloney reportedly has talked to sutter twice about coming to uniondale to replace the fired lorne henning as coach. oates sees zarins  center adam oates, who had surgery on his right ring finger a week ago to repair a torn tendon, was examined by team doctor bert zarins yesterday. zarins took the elbow-length cast off the hand and examined the stitches, which are scheduled to be removed wednesday. "it looked gruesome," said oates. "it looked like zorro had played with it. he put a new cast on it that's a little shorter, below the elbow. it's got my wrist bent at a 30-degree angle. these next couple of weeks are going to be really important. i'm not supposed to do anything at all." but the surgery has not kept oates from his favorite pastime - golf. "are you kidding?" he said. "i'd go crazy. so i'm playing one-handed and hitting off the ladies' tees.  i'm kind of skulling it. but at least i'm playing."

hl1: PARADE TO HONOR VETERANS
lede: lowell--- veterans from current and past conflicts will be honored at lowell's first home parade today. the event, which also commemorates this year's national pow/mia day, will kick off at 1 p.m. at highland street, and will proceed along gorham, central, and merrimack streets, then past a reviewing stand at city hall.
body: the parade will disband at cardinal o'connell parkway, between merrimack and market streets.     the name of the event conveys the organizers' attempt to thank veterans from previous wars, said joe dassault, lowell's director of veterans services. "a lot of veterans went to war and came back home, and nobody said thank you or anything," said dassault. he said the idea for the parade began early this year, when some veterans asked city manager john cox why the city hadn't honored older veterans. the event is sponsored by lowell's department of veterans services, the veterans of foreign wars post 662, and us representative martin t. meehan. the parade will consist of marching bands, youth groups, and vintage cars. up to 10,000 cq american flags will be distributed to children along the route. for further information, call the veterans benefits department at 978-970-4070.
copyright: Copyright 2004 Globe Newspaper Company

hl1: Filing of bill delayed;
lede: megaplex planners said they will hold off until next week in filing a bill to authorize construction of a $ 1 billion convention-sports complex. members of the special commission recommending the project continued to work on refining a fee on hotel rooms proposed as part of the financing.
body: the weld administration is exploring making the fee voluntary to avoid having it perceived as a tax. commission members said they saw no urgency to filing the bill immediately. the chairmen of the house and senate ways and means committees, who would need to work on the bill after it is filed, are tied up with budget deliberations. the panel hopes to have legislation to build the complex approved and signed by weld before the legislature recesses for the summer.

hl1: HAUNTED HOUSE TODAY
lede: chelsea    haunted house today    district 3 councilor david cleveland is scheduled to hold his third annual halloween haunted house event from 4 to 9 p.m. today on crescent avenue and forbes street. cleveland said he enjoys putting the personally financed event together for local children, "who have nothing here" to entertain them. he added the haunted house this year is "200 percent bigger" than the two previous ones, with many scary attractions, including a 14-foot-tall ghost riding a bicycle, 12-foot-tall instrument-playing ghosts, a 16-foot-tall witch, a graveyard, and frankenstein. mirrors and 32 speakers give the haunted house its finishing touches. cleveland said he expects about 700 people, weather permitting. admission is $2 for anyone over 13 years of age, and $1 for the under 13 set. - katheleen conti     everett    halloween party today    some 400 young ghosts and goblins are expected at everett's 24th annual safe halloween children's party, which will be held from 3:30 to 5:30 p.m. today at the silver fox restaurant, 530 second st. the free event, which is suitable for children through age 12, is sponsored annually by the business community under the direction of ward 1 city councilor wayne matewksy. prizes will be awarded for the most original costumes and parents are encouraged to attend, matewsky said. - caroline louise cole
body: lynn    classical high reunion    the alumni and friends of lynn classical high school will hold its third great reunion and 10th anniversary celebration on saturday at the sheraton ferncroft hotel in danvers. it is open to all graduates of classical high. the class of '74 will celebrate its 30th reunion, and the alumni association its 10th anniversary. the cocktail hour runs from 5:30 to 7 p.m., dinner and dancing from 7 to 11:45 p.m. the cost is $45 per person. tickets can be obtained from the alumni office at 781-581-5247 or by e-mailing classicalalumni@lynnschools.org. - kathy mccabe       malden    station holds food drive @matv.org. - kathy mccabe       melrose    rising school enrollment    while the overall enrollment in the melrose public schools dropped by 28 this year, from 3,619 to 3,591, school superintendent rosemary leblanc-considine said a bumper crop of kindergartners suggests the system's elementary enrollment will rise. she said the kindergarten has 289 pupils, up from last year's 246. because the current kindergarten has 24 more students than the first-grade class of 265, leblanc-considine said she anticipates the school department will have to add at least one more first-grade classroom to the current 12 next year. - caroline louise cole     revere    panel to review trash rule    the public works subcommittee is scheduled to meet at 5 p.m. tomorrow at city hall to discuss amending the city's recent change on the collection of bulky items, such as furniture and appliances. chairman ira novoselsky said mayor thomas g. ambrosino could present a plan that would reinstate the curbside collection of some bulky items for a small fee. as of last july 2004, in an effort to curb illegal dumping in the city, revere officials changed curbside pickup of bulky items to a once a month drop-off system at the city yard. this change triggered complaints from local seniors who found it difficult to make it to the yard, and from those whose property was now being used by illegal dumpers trying to cheat the system, novoselsky said. the new system could involve a sticker program, he added. - katheleen conti     saugus    leaves to be picked up    curbside leaf collection will be held this week. on their regular trash day, residents can put out bags of leaves, preferably in paper leaf bags. they should be separated from trash and recycling items. leaves will also be collected the weeks of nov. 15 and nov. 29. - kathy mccabe     wakefield    34 articles on warrant    town moderator william harbison carroll is scheduled to gavel town meeting to order at 7:30 p.m. tomorrow at the galvin middle school and, if everything goes according to plan, entertain a motion from the selectmen to continue the session to thursday at the same place and time. the board of selectmen decided to allow the meeting to open tomorrow as originally scheduled but plan to request the continuance because of the presidential election the following day. the warrant has 34 articles, including 16 to fund annual salary increases for the municipal workforce. - caroline louise cole     winthrop    high school report postponed    winthrop high principal stephen chrabaszcz was granted another extension on a progress report he was scheduled to turn in to the new england association of schools and colleges tomorrow. since march, the school has been under warning status with the association, which oversees its accreditation, partly because of a reduction of course offerings and library services due to budget cuts. in its report to school officials, the association requested a progress report to be turned in last july to see which steps had been taken to fix the issues at the school. chrabaszcz asked for and received an extension until nov. 1, but he added that weeks ago he again requested an extension until nov. 30 in order to give teachers more time to put together their findings. - katheleen conti around the region     lynnfield    tax fairness at issue    the board of selectmen meeting tomorrow will include a hearing on whether the town should classify its property tax rate this year, setting different rates for residential and business taxpayers. last year, the town classified for the first time, adopting a slightly higher rate for businesses. selectmen adopted the split rate because residential property values had increased at a higher rate than businesses, shifting a heavier tax burden onto homeowners, according to town administrator bill gustus. the hearing tomorrow will include a presentation by the town's assessors on property growth among the different classes of taxpayers. selectmen are expected to vote on the classification question following the hearing. also at the meeting, the recreation commission is scheduled to discuss with selectmen a plan for improving fields in town, and a proposed fee for field users to support maintenance and improvement costs. the meeting will be held in the selectmen's room in town hall, starting at 6:30 p.m. - john laidler     medford    school proposal must be revisited    the city's school reuse committee will have to reconsider its proposal for the former forest park school on governor's avenue. the city was seeking a developer last month to demolish the building and construct three single-family homes on the site. but no one bid on the property, which was on the market for $1.1. million. - angelica medaglia     nahant    bed-and-breakfast proposed    selectmen are scheduled to discuss a proposed bed-and-breakfast on lafayette terrace and hear the results of the town's year-end audit at the board of selectmen's meeting scheduled for 7:30 p.m. thursday. the meeting will be held at town hall, nahant road. - david rattigan     peabody    affordable housing quotas    the planning board has scheduled a hearing nov. 18 on proposed revisions to the city's two-year-old inclusionary zoning ordinance. the hearing will be part of an overall planning board meeting at the public services department building on 50 farm ave., beginning at 7 p.m. the proposed changes were developed by a council subcommittee and the community development and planning department. the full council received the proposals on oct. 21 and sent them to the planning board for review. after the nov. 18 hearing, the board is expected to offer its recommendations on the proposed changes and forward them to the council. the council will then hold its own hearing on the changes on dec. 9, before voting on them.    the current ordinance requires that 15 percent of the units of all multifamily residential developments of eight units or more be classified as affordable. one proposed change would extend that requirement to single-family developments. another would make the definition of affordable housing in the ordinance fit with the state's definition. that would ensure that all affordable units built under the ordinance could be counted in calculating the city's affordable-housing numbers. the state requires that 10 percent of a community's housing stock be classified as affordable. - john laidler     salem    last day of halloween fest    closing ceremonies for the 25th annual haunted happenings family festival will be held at 5 p.m. today at 288 derby st. as part of the event, the festival's king and queen will be crowned, along with the prince and princess of halloween. also street entertainers, bands, and disc jockeys will provide entertainment. for more information call 978-740-2929. - steven rosenberg

hl1: Prime-time faceoff for big money;
lede: a hardball showdown over the megabucks from prime-time television could shift the uneasy balance of power between the three television networks and hollywood's major movie studios over providing entertainment to 120 million american homes. the prize could be the hundreds of millions of dollars to be made from the sale of prime-time television shows to other broadcast outlets here and abroad. but the cost might be further control of hollywood's creative process by the;networks, which have been blocked for years by tough government regulation. many writers and producers fear this homogenization might limit even further the already limited diversity and message of many tv shows.
body: in a last ditch attempt at compromise, robert daley, president of warner bros., the movie studio arm of time warner, conceded last week that the producers of product in california might agree to sell the networks in new york a financial interest in every show produced in hollywood.  as part of the bargain, though, daley, acting on behalf of a consortium of independent producers, unaffiliated television stations and movie studios, indicated the networks would be required, among other things, to absorb part of the deficits incurred in producing the programs, and would be limited in their scheduling of these programs.  this concession was recommended by independent programming producers, who are suffering because their weekly operating deficits are much greater than the weekly license fees from the networks, says jerry leider, who along with daley, is part of the hollywood negotiating team. the networks though, are not buying the concession. "the studios want safeguards so overwhelming that it amounts to a straitjacket we couldn't accept," says a network executive familiar with the negotiations.  jack valenti, president of the motion picture association, the trade group representing the movie studios, says the offer of a financial interest is "a breakthrough. but, they the networks want more. they don't want any rules at all," he says.  "i'm really dismayed by the networks. they want to be totally competitive with the studios. they believe they can go before the fcc year after year and get what they want," adds valenti.  at issue is the right - now largely denied to nbc, cbs and abc - to produce more prime-time programming, to benefit financially from this ownership, and to sell these shows to tv outlets abroad.  the networks are prohibited from having a financial interest in more than five of the 22 hours of prime-time television - programs viewed between 8 p.m. and 11 p.m. each night of the week, except for sunday night, when prime time starts at 7 p.m. what's more they can only sell these five hours of shows to television operators abroad and are not allowed to profit from the domestic syndication of any prime-time programs. these restrictions are about to be loosened, some wall street analysts, congressional specialists and network negotiators believe.  for one thing, the federal communications commission temporarily awarded fox broadcasting co., the television arm of rupert murdoch's news corp. global communications empire, a waiver in april, allowing it to act like both a movie studio and a television network, at least until the end of 1990. unlike the other networks, fox has the unlimited right to produce and syndicate here and abroad its own television shows, in which it has the controlling financial interest.  the move has encouraged wall street about the prospects of the networks.  "there will be a modification that will allow the networks to produce 50 percent of their programs and allow syndication of this 50 percent," says alan kassan, a morgan stanley entertainment analyst.  this would mean the networks could produce and have a financial interest in 11 hours of the 22 hours of prime-time television, and control the distribution of those programs to their affiliates in the united states and to the fast-growing european market.  kassan also believes the potential rule change will facilitate the "affiliation or merger of the three networks with the movie studios."  preston padden, a fox senior vice president, says, however, that there is "a perpetual prohibition in the consent decree against the networks having a financial interest. even if the fcc changes the rules for them they must go to court and modify it." the final resolution of this battle depends, in part, on negotiations between the networks and the motion picture association, which will be renewed this week. if a compromise cannot be reached by thursday, the fcc will hold hearings to resolve the matter by year-end.  some independent movie producers are worried that if the networks get their way, they will become captives of three large buyers of entertainment product. "the programming choices will be narrower because the perceptions will be narrower. the yardstick will be how much three gateway networks are going to make, rather than how good the idea is," says lillian gallo, an independent filmmaker in california, who once worked at abc.  the outcome of this battle also will affect the livelihoods of hundreds of independent television stations like viacom, the entertainment complex controlled by sumner redstone, a wealthy boston businessman.  cbs, abc and nbc want the chance to emulate viacom, which has grossed about $ 600 million from selling the hit cosby show, which originated on nbc, in reruns to independent television stations here and abroad. independent television stations also fear for their livelihood, even though many are part of the fox network or belong to paramount, disney, mca and the tribune co., publisher of the chicago tribune.  "the viewers will be given less choice of programs if the networks can control the best shows, and warehouse them for network affiliate stations," says ed trimble, general manager of ktvt in dallas. "we oppose any change at all."

hl1: Sexually transmitted disease rates fall;
lede: rates of sexually transmitted disease and births to teen-agers continue to drop in massachusetts, according to statistics released yesterday, leading health officials to speculate that the message about safe sex in the age of aids may be sinking in. in 1994, the state's teen-age birth rate fell to 31.2 for every 1,000 women aged 15 through 19, down from 31.5 in 1993 and a high of 35.9 in 1989. the overall number of births to massachusetts women under 20 was 6,567 in 1994, down from a recent high of 7,734 in 1989. last year, syphilis cases dropped 22 percent, from 378 in 1994 to 294 in 1995. gonorrhea decreased 16 percent, from 3,156 to 2,658 cases in 1995, while chlamydia fell 8 percent, from 8,049 to 7,402 cases.
body: "obviously, something is happening in the larger community to assist these numbers in going down," said state public health commissioner david mulligan at a meeting yesterday of the public health council, the policy-making arm of the state health department, where the numbers were released. "is it worries about aids? more condom use? less sex?" said mulligan. causes for the decline, particularly of the std cases, may be too complicated to clearly determine, but they are probably related to the various local, state, federal and community programs to prevent the spread of hiv, the virus that causes aids, said paul etkind, director of the public health department's division of std prevention. "if somebody is going to take to heart a message to prevent hiv, and they act on it, they're going to be at lower risk for gonorrhea, syphilis and chlamydia as well," said etkind. while the overall numbers of teen-age births and std cases have dropped statewide, certain populations are still at high risk, causing continued concern for public health officials. for instance, hispanics have the highest teen-age birth rate, 121.6 births for every 1,000 women aged 15 through 19; for black non-hispanics, the rate is 90 per 1,000 women, and for asians, 32.7 per 1,000. while white non-hispanics have the lowest rate, 23.8 births per 1,000, they constituted more than half of all new teen-age mothers in the state. similar racial disparities exist in the std cases, but as mulligan pointed out, such differences may reflect socioeconomic status rather than race. but public health officials added that programs to prevent stds and teen-age births must be sensitive to language and cultural differences that exist. another public health report released yesterday, of fatal injuries at work in 1994, showed that the top four causes of death on the job remain the same as in previous years, although the rankings have shifted slightly. of the 62 men and 9 women who died as a result of injuries on the job in 1994, 12 died in motor vehicle crashes; 11 as a result of homicide, related to police duties or robberies of retail stores; nine as a result of falls; and nine from fishing and boating activities. in other action, the public health council voted to finalize a regulation implementing the new state law requiring most insurers to cover a minimum 48-hour hospital stay after a vaginal delivery and 96-hour stay after a caesarean section, unless women and doctors agree to an earlier discharge. the only substantive amendment to the regulation changes the hours during which hospitals cannot discharge patients, to between 8 p.m. and 8 a.m. some women's health advocates wanted an expansion of the regulation so that certain providers, such as doulas, can make home visits to women discharged early. but public health officials said that change could not be made because the law as passed requires a physician, a registered nurse or a certified nurse-midwife to make the first home visit and a licensed health care provider to make any subsequent visits. doulas are women who come to the home a few hours a day to help new mothers with such skills as breastfeeding and to provide support by cooking meals or running errands.  a welcome drop in stds, teen-age births  figures released yesterday show a continued slide of sexually transmitted diseases.…

hl1: FIRMER FOUNDATIONS
lede: philanthropy has an honest reputation that's being tarnished by the actions of a few greedy trustees and staff members who pay themselves far too handsomely. the massachusetts attorney general and prosecutors in other states are looking into evidence of abuse reported last month by the globe's spotlight team. among the subjects was paul c. cabot jr., who gave himself a raise to pay for his daughter's $200,000 wedding. cabot's salary hit a high of $1.4 million. during the same time period, the foundation donated an annual average of only $400,000.
body: this summer, researchers at the georgetown public policy institute pointed to similar problems in a report on trustee fees paid by large and small foundations. in 1998, the 238 that were surveyed paid $44.9 million in trustee fees. fourteen of the large foundations paid trustees more than $100,000 each. foundations have tax-exempt status because they contribute to the greater good. to survive and prosper, they need the public's trust. excessive compensation drains money away from charity and creates an intolerable stain for the many selfless trustees who work for little or no money. several things should be done. states should increase enforcement. in massachusetts, the attorney general's office is working with other states and the urban institute, a washington think tank, to develop software that can analyze foundations' tax forms. the challenge will be getting all foundations - in particular small ones with limited administrative resources - to submit this information in a form that software can read. and it will take human investigators to spot more deceptive practices such as funneling money to trustees by contracting with companies they own. more critically, the foundation community should police itself. the council on foundations, an association of more than 2,000 donor institutions, points out that self-policing is the one way to avoid "uninformed, politically motivated scrutiny of foundations and philanthropy" that could lead to damaging tax changes or regulations. the council should expand its outreach and education and promote honorable whistle blowing, encouraging board members or relatives to report abuses. while egregious cases should be prosecuted, some abusers would benefit from guidance in cleaning up messes and instituting best practices. the council has helped a dozen donors over the past seven years. this effort should be expanded. the internal revenue service has other pressing work. but a small increase in money and attention could buoy the work of states and associations. philanthropy's heart beats to put money where it can do the most good. this sector should have the cleanest accounts possible.

hl1: UK ends pet shop puppy, kitten sales
lede: london — britain has banned third-party sales of puppies and kittens to protect the animals from exploitation. the government says the new law will help crack down on "puppy farms" and make it harder for unscrupulous dealers who have little regard for animal welfare. animal welfare minister david rutley said the ban "is part of our commitment to make sure the nation's much-loved pets get the right start in life."
body: body the decision follows a public consultation that found overwhelming support for banning third-party sales. under the new measure, people wishing to adopt a puppy or kitten would have to deal directly with a breeder or a re-homing center, rather than pet shops or other commercial dealers. animal welfare groups praised the government measure as an important step forward. associated press

hl1: HEALEY NEEDS LESSON ON ELDER AFFAIRS
lede: i was astonished to read the article "healey rapped on senior tax issue" (city & region, march 22). what is our lieutenant governor thinking? governor romney should send her for a course on senior issues 101.
body: i serve on the council on aging in natick. one of our primary responsibilities is to link older adult needs with resources. this is done with the goal of helping seniors maintain their independence and improve their quality of life. no senior should feel isolated in his own community.    it has been my experience that seniors prefer to stay in their homes as long as they can. their home is their castle. they do not feel "overhoused" there. for many, their house is the only thing they have to leave to their children or grandchildren. it is important for them to be able to leave something to their loved ones.         i'm sure the executive office of elder affairs at the state house could apprise kerry healey of senior concerns in today's society. heaven help the commonwealth if she ever gets the power to put into practice her preposterous notions.    jerry l. pierce   natick

hl1: Eastern Standard restaurateur Garrett Harker on Red Sox fever
hl2: When your restaurant's in Boston's Kenmore Square, you obsess about baseball's opening day. Harker explains.
lede: the rhythm of the red sox moves all of us here. we have meetings about what kind of hiring we need, then the staff training will happen, then we have the all-staff meeting [on april 6]. there are the logistical challenges of the day-to-day issues of having that much activity through the space.
body: we learned early on that it has a huge psychological impact, both positive and sometimes negative. you can feel the optimism of when the season starts, and if the sox are having a good year, you feel the energy in the restaurant. when the sox aren't doing well, it feels like the season is long and dragging. we don't see it so much in the volume of bodies, though. but when the sox are losing, people order a beer and a burger, and when the sox are flying high, people order more steaks and red wine. we're in the restaurant business, so we like high levels of stimulation. for us, we all get fired up when there's activity at fenway. not just the red sox: i think there's three or four concerts already booked for fenway park this summer. for any activity over there, we feel we're in the hub. it's the heartbeat of the city when there's activity over there. one of our all-staff meetings was actually held at fenway park, and [sox ceo] larry lucchino kicked it off saying how we elevate the fans' experience and how we all work in synch and do the same thing, which is creating a great fan experience. we celebrate our 10th year in may. in the beginning, there was a feeling of we've just got to survive. now we're more in command of what we're doing, and we're a part of a night out at fenway park.  to visit eastern standard will be closed for lunch april 6 for its all-staff meeting. otherwise it's open seven days a week from 7 a.m. to 2 a.m. 617-532-9100; easternstandardboston.com

hl1: Savor the flavors of summer at a local farm
lede: the love dogs will perform on saturday at the black box theatre in franklin. an image from the film "the shadow of the house," to be screened at concord museum on wednesday. corn roasts enjoy local produce on a historic farm at gore place's series of friday evening corn roasts, taking place aug. 11, 18, and 25 from 5 to 7 p.m. the menu includes locally grown roasted corn and baked potatoes with toppings as well as herb-infused lemonade, along with craft activities for children. food sold a la carte. gore place is located at 52 gore st., waltham. for more information, call 781-894-2798 or go to www.goreplace.org. scenic eating powisset farm offers a seasonal dinner against a backdrop of scenic views of the farm at sunset on both friday, aug. 11, and friday, aug. 25, from 6 to 8 p.m. prepared by renowned chef and cookbook author didi emmons, the dinner event includes a multicourse meal, nonalcoholic beverages (beer and wine will be available for purchase), and entertainment. an optional staff-led farm tour will begin at 5:30 p.m. tickets are $36 per adult, $12 per child for members; $45 per adult, $15 per child for nonmembers. powisset farm is located at 37 powisset st., dover. for more information, call 508-785-0339, ext. 3003
body: body gone fishin' the spellman museum of stamps & postal history at regis college in weston is celebrating summer with a special exhibit called "summer and stamps, gone fishin' " on view now through sept. 30. the exhibit includes stamps featuring fish, the world's oceans, and a special section about whales on stamps. the museum's ongoing jkf centennial display is also on view. hands-on activities for children and adults include stamp scavenger hunts, making collections of presidents and animals on stamps, creating stamp fish mosaics, and more. admission is $8 for adults, $5 for seniors, $3 for children (5-16). the museum is located at 241 wellesley st., weston. for more information call 617-784-5838 or go to www.spellmanmuseum.org. film screening join documentary film director allie humenuk at the concord museum on wednesday, aug. 9, at 7 p.m. for a free screening of her new film "the shadow of the house." it depicts seven years in the life of photographer abelardo morell and his family both at home and abroad, including his return to cuba for the first time since his escape in 1962. morell's works at the concord museum include "walden: four views," a new interpretation of the landscape that inspired henry david thoreau's "walden." the exhibit will be open to film screening attendees beginning at 6 p.m. admission to the film is free; to reserve a space, go to www.concordmuseum.org or call 978-369-9763, ext. 216. the concord museum is located at 200 lexington road, concord. rhythm & blues the black box theatre's summer concert series features rhythm and blues band the love dogs on saturday, aug. 12, at 8 p.m. with barrelhouse boogie-woogie piano, fender guitar, and a horn section of trombone and alto, tenor, and baritone saxes, the love dogs showcases a swinging rhythm section and a charismatic front man. tickets are $20 for adults and $15 for students and seniors. a cash bar is available. the black box, the home of the franklin performing arts company, is located at 15 west central st., franklin. for more information or to purchase tickets, call 508-528-3370 or go to www.theblackboxonline.com. baroque opera opera del west is celebrating summer by exploring a new genre: baroque opera, combined with dance. the company will premiere this new approach with a full-length performance of handel's "alcina" at the center for arts in natick on friday, aug. 11, at 8 p.m. and sunday, aug. 13, at 2 p.m. the opera, sung in italian with english supertitles, depicts the story of an insatiable sorceress who lures men to her island and then turns them into flora and fauna. it will also be the first opera del west production that includes members of the local dance troupe paradise lost. the center for arts in natick is located at 14 summer st., natick. tickets are $25 general admission, $20 members, and can be purchased by calling 508-647-0097 or going to www.natickarts.org. send ideas to nancyswest@gmail.com

hl1: Mass. to get $ 1m food-stamp bonus;
lede: massachusetts will receive nearly $ 1 million in extra federal funds tomorrow for having one of the lowest error rates nationally in food stamp distributions.
body: the state's error rate, which peaked at just over 13 percent in 1990, stood at 5.76 percent last year, the eighth lowest in the nation. under federal law, states with error rates below 5.9 percent qualify for extra funds. dick powers, spokesman for the state department of transitional assistance, attributed the reduction to an administrative crackdown on errors and a computer matching program that helps caseworkers identify ineligible recipients.

hl1: Bob Schloredt, two-time Rose Bowl MVP
lede: seattle — bob schloredt, a college football hall of fame member and the first two-time mvp of the rose bowl, has died.
body: body mr. schloredt was 79. the university of washington issued a statement announcing the death on thursday night on behalf of mr. schloredt's family. mr. schloredt led washington to consecutive rose bowl victories following the 1959 and 1960 seasons. mr. schloredt shared mvp honors with george fleming in first rose bowl victory over wisconsin. a year later, the huskies beat no. 1 minnesota 17-7 and mr. schloredt had one touchdown rushing and one passing to earn mvp honors again. mr. schloredt was a first-team ap all-american in 1959 as a two-way player. he led washington with six interceptions that season. mr. schloredt was inducted into the college football hall of fame in 1989.

hl1: Testing, and roiling, political waters
hl2: Sen. Rand Paul draws attention with barbed comments in N.H.
lede: manchester, n.h. — with the political world focused on a potential republican presidential primary matchup between former florida governor jeb bush and former massachusetts governor mitt romney, kentucky senator rand paul traveled to new hampshire on wednesday and injected himself back into the national conversation with a series of provocative statements.
body: while state legislators ate eggs and drank coffee in a manchester diner, paul suggested that half of the recipients of federal disability relief are "gaming the system" because they are able to work. he also told them the arguments against building the keystone xl pipeline are "this sort of luddite, flat-earth, that my goodness we shouldn't have cars" mentality. to gun-rights advocates at the londonderry fish and game club, he talked about how the militarization of local police forces contributes to the nation's poor race relations. in ferguson, mo., he said, "it looks like the army is there, so if you are an african-american in ferguson, you think the white police have an army and they are after me." speaking to education advocates at a manchester charter school, he called for abolishing the us department of education and whacked the common core standards because, he said, they stifle innovation. if those comments didn't get him attention, he also offered reporters quotable zingers about his potential party rivals, dismissing bush and romney as "yesterday's news." paul also confirmed wednesday that he hired a presidential campaign manager, even though he repeatedly said during the day he won't make up his mind on whether he'll run until march or april. it was paul's comments about disability benefits that drew the most attention, largely because democrats quickly pounced. during a question-and-answer period, paul was asked about government programs and welfare. "you know, the thing is that all of these programs — there's always somebody who is deserving. everybody in this room knows somebody who is gaming the system," said paul. "what i tell people is, if you look like me and you hop out of your truck, you shouldn't be getting a disability check," paul said. "you know, over half the people on disability are either anxious or their back hurts. join the club. who doesn't get up a little anxious for work every day and their back hurts? everybody over 40 has a back pain." new hampshire democratic party chairman ray buckley called the comments "insulting" to those who collect disability payments, and "ridiculously reminiscent" of romney's statement in 2012 that 47 percent of americans vote democratic because they rely on government support. "paul is saying that 50 percent of those on disability are committing fraud," he said. paul released a statement later in the day saying, "we absolutely should take care of those truly in need of help. but the system is broken, and when people can game the system, they are stealing from those who are truly disabled and won't receive the care and aid they need." james pindell can be reached at james.pindell@globe.com follow him on twitter @jamespindell.

hl1: Some Fidelity college savings plans now offer other companies' mutual funds
lede: fidelity investmentsis opening up some of its college savings plans by including other companies' mutual funds on its menu of investment options, rather than restricting investors to fidelity funds. boston-based fidelity, the third-largest manager of 529 college savings plans, unveiled the change yesterday. here are the basics:
body: background section 529 plans are named after part of the federal tax code. they let parents withdraw money for college expenses free of federal taxes. there are notable tax benefits for those going this route, compared with stashing the savings in bank accounts or certificates of deposit. each plan is sponsored by a state that can set its own guidelines, including offering tax deductions or credits. investors aren't limited to their own state's plan. open or closed? traditionally, 529 plans have restricted investment options to mutual funds from the company that is managing the plan. however, some 529s have adopted ``open-architecture'' approaches, where the investment menu includes funds offered by other companies that might deliver superior investment performance. open-architecture plans typically charge higher fees. who can participate fidelity's expanded menu is available nationwide in four 529 plans: fidelity arizona college savings plan, delaware college investment plan, massachusetts u. fund college investing plan, and new hampshire unique college investing plan. collectively, they manage $9.3 billion, or nearly 8 percent of all assets in 529 plans. the new options the outside funds investors in the fidelity 529 plans can now choose from are selected by fidelity. examples of funds with strong performance records include jpmorgan us equity, mfs international value, and pimco total return. plan portfolios typically hold a mix of funds that invest in stocks, bonds, and money-market investments. as a child gets closer to college age, the investment mix becomes more conservative. that shift reduces the potential for a big loss just as a student needs to draw from the savings. fees program fees and expenses associated with the new options run from 0.93 to 1.42 percent of plan assets. that's more costly than the 529 options that fidelity continues to offer using only in-house funds. fees and expenses range from 0.57 to 1.06 percent for a 529 plan option in which assets are invested in funds that rely on professional managers to pick investments. the range is 0.25 to 0.35 percent for 529s that invest in index funds which passively track market indexes. mark jewell writes for the associated press.

hl1: Brandeis: Renting out art for art's sake
lede: brandeis university is raising eyebrows in the museum world with its plans to lend out artworks for money, but exploring this option is a reasonable way to preserve the financially strapped school's collection.
body: last year, brandeis considered closing the renowned rose art museum and selling off some of its 7,500 objects. had that happened, both the school and the region would have been worse off for it. now, the globe recently reported, the school is hiring auction house sotheby's as a lending broker. collecting fees from institutions that might want to display some of the museum's works could generate badly needed funding and might even increase awareness of the rose as well. the rose, like many other museums, owns more works than it can display. in the past, museums lent artworks to one another and charged mainly for the costs of shipping and insurance. but tougher times justify a more entrepreneurial approach. in recent years, a major atlanta museum paid $7 million to borrow works from the louvre. one can, of course, take the profit mind-set to an extreme: the museum of fine arts did just that in 2004, when it lent most of its monets to a gallery in a las vegas casino for more than $1 million. more helpful to brandeis, perhaps, would be a reliable stream of more modest fees. some caveats apply: brandeis should only lend to institutions capable of caring for its artworks. and it should use any revenues to guarantee a future for the rose. because the economics of maintaining a museum can be forbidding, brandeis deserves praise, not criticism, for trying to raise revenue through its collection.

hl1: A beginner's guide to buying an older home
hl2: Massachusetts is stocked with vintage properties, full of charm, but also quirks. Here's some expert advice for spotting potential problems and shopping smart.
author: By Jon Gorey
lede: our electrician was working in the attic when my wife heard the unmistakable gush of a waterfall coming from the linen closet. she opened the door to find hot water cascading onto the sheets and towels — the result of a burst brass pipe, jostled just enough to be ruptured by the electrician drilling into a joist 15 feet away. we'd hired him to rewire our 1920 house, which, in addition to charming details like a built-in hutch and butler's pantry, also had a lot of original knob-and-tube wiring. and old brass water pipes, which grow brittle as they age. now we'd be hiring a plumber, too. there are things you ought to know before buying an old house — among them, the names of a few reliable tradespeople. but the crooked charms, cranky quirks, and enduring craftsmanship of an antique abode tend to be worth the accompanying headaches for a lot of homeowners, especially in history-addled new england. "it's a way of life," says jay rizzo, co-owner of tiger home inspections in braintree. "some people really enjoy it."
body: body not that you always have a choice in the matter if you're house hunting in and around boston. the median massachusetts home was 53 years old in 2015 — making ours the second-oldest housing stock in the nation — and urban housing tends to be even older. four out of five homes in boston were built before 1978 and half predate world war ii; a whopping 68 percent of somerville's housing was already in place by 1939. so there's a good chance you'll end up in an old home whether you intended to or not. here's what experts say you should know before living in the past. while the late '70s may not feel like "historic" territory, realtor and antique homes magazine founder john petraglia says a home is like any other mechanical system, with an internal clock good for about 30 years. "so really you're looking at the same things whether you're buying a house from 1975 or 1775," petraglia says. all homebuyers, first-time or otherwise, need to get professional inspections of the mechanicals — the electrical system, the roof, the plumbing, heating. "they all have a useful life span," he says. but older homes sometimes have components rarely used in modern construction, such as wooden gutters or steam radiators. those are two systems that, with regular maintenance, can be perfectly fine. even a centuries-old home can be in better shape than a neglected newer one — and there's one place to find out. "the basement is the make-or-break spot for old houses," petraglia says. "because there's so many mechanicals there to look at. you can see the structural frame to see if the beams are intact or if insects have attacked them and they're ready to be renewed. look at the heating, electric, and plumbing systems and the foundation itself." old homes have had decades or even centuries for wood-boring insects to find their way in — and infestations weren't uncommon in the days before kiln-dried lumber, rizzo says. but even extensive termite damage doesn't have to be a deal breaker. "everything can be fixed, to a point, it just costs money," rizzo says, noting that any piece of timber that's more than 25 percent damaged by insects generally ought to be replaced. nor should buyers panic about sloped floors or small cracks in the foundation or main beam, says home inspector harold popp, owner of mt. vernon inspection associates in middleton. "almost all of these old stone foundations have some cracks in them," popp says. "should they be repaired, is it an emergency? most of the time, it's not," he says. but a home inspector may suggest hiring a structural engineer just to be sure. most people are willing to live with slightly sloping floors, says realtor john neale, the historian for the south end historical society. "if you've got a home that's really, really out of level, you may not want to buy it unless you can spend the money to level the floors — which can be done," neale says. "if a staircase is really sagging visibly, that's worth fixing," he adds. while there's no reason to be afraid of old houses, you should brace yourself for the unknown. old homes are full of surprises, which can lead to unexpected costs, rizzo says. "repairs that would be regular maintenance on a newer home are going to cost more because sometimes when you open things up, you open up a can of worms. it might be a lot bigger than just replacing a pipe." you might think you'll just swap in a new vanity to update the bathroom, for example, but find things aren't so simple. if some of the piping is brass, as in my house, "that could break any time  .  .  .  so it might require all new plumbing," says popp. older piping isn't necessarily a problem. "cast iron and copper have been around for a very long time and have served homeowners very well," says susan jacobs-marshalsea of s jacobs plumbing in norwood. "there are exceptions, but on average they shouldn't be an issue" if they're in good condition. she says, however, that galvanized, threaded pipe ought to be replaced, because it is known to rust, which can lead to blockages. even if an old home has been completely renovated with all-new pvc pipes and drains, it might still have a cast iron drain line to the street. "that may have been underground for 80 years, and that can really be a problem," says popp. for instance, if an older person has been living alone for years and a family of five moves in, the added strain can be the tipping point that collapses the drain, he says. meanwhile, insuring an older home can be its own challenge: our car insurance company refused to write a policy on our home because of the knob-and-tube wiring. jim hyatt, senior vice president at arbella insurance in quincy, suggests independent insurance agents. "they have a lot of experience, particularly in new england, with people buying older properties," he says. while it can cost more to insure an old house, hyatt says bundling your car and homeowners policies can save you 20 to 25 percent on the latter. updating old wiring, plumbing, and the roof usually will lead to lower premiums. old homes may not have much, if any, insulation, either, making them more expensive to heat and cool. local and state incentives can make energy upgrades more affordable. likewise, some incentives exist to address issues like lead paint (banned in 1978) and asbestos (widely used in residential construction until the late 1970s). neale says safety, energy, and major system upgrades are always a good idea, but he urges buyers to pause before overhauling a historic interior and stripping its timeless charms. "those details are 100-, 150-plus years old, and they've survived this long. if you want to be the one to get rid of that detail for all time, think carefully before you do it," he says. buyers sometimes feel compelled to update everything about an old home after moving in, but the budget pressures of taking on so much at once can force them to make decisions they'll later regret. clean and modern is the current trend, neale says, but he recommends looking at how european designers integrate minimalist style with old world details like crown molding and wide window casings, because contemporary features have a shorter shelf life. "once you remove original detail completely  .  .  .  the interior starts to age pretty quickly, meaning people can walk in and within a few years guess precisely what year you did that renovation." preserving a home's unique features can help achieve a timeless look. neale also suggests using a preservation-minded contractor, because most remodelers find it easier and cheaper to just remove old details than to work around or restore them. "the average contractor won't want to deal with those things, it's just a nuisance for them," he says. "but when you see the outside of a beautiful old house and you walk in and it's like you've gone from the 19th century to the bridge of the starship enterprise, it's very jarring." some big improvements, like fixing masonry issues, may go unnoticed by prospective buyers, unfortunately. "it's not like a new bath — it's the nitty-gritty work that costs a lot to do properly," neale says. in other words, these are essential and expensive fixes, but they won't wow buyers like a new kitchen would. "so if a house needs that kind of work," neale adds, "make sure you're not overpaying for it, that you've priced that work into the offer you make on the property." all of this may sound daunting, but rizzo says there's been so much turnover in the boston area that many problematic issues have already been addressed as homes have changed hands over the years. the key is whether they were done well: popp says he often comes across substandard repairs performed by previous homeowners or unlicensed contractors. bill delaney, a veteran inspector and supervisor with tiger, recommends any home buyer make a trip to city hall. "find the folder on the house and see what repairs have been done," he says. "have they pulled permits? did they get sign-off? who did the work? that's a great resource for any buyer on any house, but especially on an older home." why bother with all this trouble? for one thing, the materials and craftsmanship found in old homes are increasingly rare commodities. original three-piece crown molding, ceiling medallions, and ornate mantels aren't exactly a growth market. "there's so many good qualities in an older home but it really shows in the finish: beautiful trim work, the staircase," delaney says. "usually you're running into true wood panels on the wall that someone hand hewed." petraglia loves the hand-carved moldings and five fireplaces in his 1780 home, but also the historical context he gets to share. "i know the history of the family that built this house, and it just creates a continuum for me to know who and where and what and feel like i'm a part of it," he says. "i look at historic houses as homes, not as museums. they're places to live — and they're the glue in the fabric of our architectural history." from knob-and-tube wiring and brittle brass pipes to sloping floors and uninsulated walls, we slowly remedied virtually every old home challenge mentioned in this story. it's been costly, frustrating, and exhausting at times — but also extremely rewarding. what's more, it was the house we could afford in the neighborhood we loved, and it kindly gave us shelter as we gradually addressed its many flaws — so that it might one day be defined not by its defects but by its details. and now? we wouldn't trade it for a brand-new house if we could. jon gorey is a writer in quincy. send comments to magazine@globe.com

hl1: CRASH COURSE
hl2: FORMER MASSPORT DIRECTOR STEPHEN P. TOCCO HAS STEPPED ON A LOT OF TOES IN HIS CAREER. NOW GOVERNOR
author: BY SARAH SCHWEITZER, GLOBE STAFF
lede: friends and foes agree on this much about stephen p. tocco: the man sure can make trouble, but he knows how to make nice. after sparring and nearly reaching the point of no return with a challenger, the chairman of the state board of higher education is known to flash his impish smile, let loose his low-key humor, and deflate explosive situations of his own making. "i was livid," said representative kevin murphy, house chairman of the joint committee on higher education, who said tocco blindsided him last fall by publicly rolling out a financial aid proposal without consulting him. "but he said he wanted a heart-to-heart. when our meeting was over, i said, `this is a guy i can work with.' " now, as tocco, 59, seeks to win the chairmanship of the university of massachusetts board of trustees, the question is whether his aggressive style would propel umass-amherst into a top-flight flagship or bog down the board in one-upmanship and recriminations.
body: tocco vies for the spot amid controversy. he says he has the votes to unseat karl white , the chairman, at a special meeting set for thursday, but others say his election pushed by governor mitt romney is not a fait accompli. tocco, whose style has made him a go-to man in successive republican administrations, says he must act as a consensus builder to be successful among the 19 voting members on the umass board. but during an interview in his 41st-floor office in downtown boston, tocco said he is prepared to do battle to fulfill romney's mandate to elevate the profile of umass-amherst by improving its campus and its national rankings. "umass-amherst becomes the brand of the public system," tocco said. critics, higher education officials who would talk only off the record about their concerns, say tocco's plan could put the five campuses, which now act like miniempires, on a collision course. while some say that tocco owes his ascension to the umass board to his close political ties to romney, others contend that tocco has become well-versed in higher education policy in the seven years he has headed the state board of higher education. state officials and educators credit him for pushing through key initiatives, including improving state and community college graduation rates. the initiative initially met with resistance, but college officials say tocco was dogged and eventually swayed college leaders. state college graduation rates in the past three years have gone from 44 percent to 49 percent. "there has been tension between tocco and the president of the institutions," said dana mohler-faria, president of bridgewater state college. "but it was the sort of tension that caused the system to move forward." robert antonucci, president of fitchburg state college, put it this way: "steve is steve. he's upfront, he's honest. sometimes he may step on toes, but to get the system moving, you can't be a fly on the wall." tocco says the clash over graduation rates was necessary. "the college presidents said i was supposed to be their advocate," he said. "i said, `i can't be an advocate if i don't believe in the product.' " tocco grew up in malden and later reading, the son of a milk delivery man and stay-at-home mother. the oldest of five children, tocco was an avid athlete at reading high school and carried himself with an intense demeanor, his siblings recall. "god love him," said mary cookson, his sister. "he was never afraid to take the bull by the horns." tocco earned a bachelor of science in pharmacy and chemistry from the massachusetts college of pharmacy in 1969, although tocco says he never intended to make a career in pharmacy. he developed an interest in public policy in 1976 when he campaigned for his childhood friend, edward j. markey, as he sought his first term in congress. tocco soon after began running markey's district office. "steve was a natural leader," markey said. "he could take any issue and work with people to try to reach consensus." in 1980, tocco left politics to head associated builders and contractors, a trade association. eleven years later, he returned to politics as a senior aide to governor william f. weld, who, a year later, named tocco secretary of economic affairs. in 1993, weld tapped him to head the massachusetts port authority, where he stayed for four years, and clashed with then-senate president william m. bulger over how a sports and convention center would be paid for and designed. in 1997, he joined an international trade unit of the law firm mintz levin cohn ferris glovsky and popeo, and two years later, became head of the firm's lobbying arm, ml strategies, after its merger with the trade unit, the same year he was tapped to head the state board of higher education to critics, tocco's dual role, as higher education czar and head of a lobbying firm of a law firm that touts higher education as a specialty, is a collision of interests. "a person in that position has to be able to stand up and advocate for the wishes of the university against the wishes of the governor and the legislature, and i don't know if you can do that if you are in the position that steve tocco is in as president of ml strategies," said james karam, the umass board of trustees chairman who was ousted by romney this month. umass trustees oversee a budget of $2.1 billion. tocco says he has sought to avoid conflicts of interest and has recused himself from board of higher education votes that awarded his law firm work as legal counsel to umass as it secured financing for construction. tocco does not register as a lobbyist because he says he runs ml strategies, but does not lobby on its clients' behalf. he said ml strategies, which has five registered lobbyists, does not represent any institutions of higher education. state records show the firm represented boston university in 2004, but tocco says it no longer does. tocco declined to provide a client list. "he doesn't have a self-interested agenda," said robert o'leary of the cape and islands, who is the senate chair of the joint committee on higher education. "he really is an advocate for the system." tocco still lives in reading with his wife, cynthia bouthot tocco, who works for the british consulate, and has three grown children. in his spare time, he said, he plays golf in reading. but he says that time is limited: there is always background reading. tocco says he's gearing up for clashes anew if he wins control of the board. "disagreement is healthy," he said. "if everyone agrees, i worry that i missed something." sarah schweitzer can be reached at schweitzer@globe.com. sidebar: mixed grades stephen p. tocco has made a career of pushing bold proposals and fighting off naysayers. he's offended many in the process, and at times his proposals have failed. failing in 1993, as head of massport, tocco spearheaded an effort to build a stadium in downtown boston. ticked off: legislators, including senate president william m. bulger, who opposed the deal. result: proposal was dead-on-arrival in the legislature. in 1988, as head of associated builders and contractors, tocco led a campaign to repeal the state's prevailing wage law. ticked off: organized labor. result: referendum defeated; tocco received a black funeral wreath with a note attached wishing that he and his campaign "rest in peace." passing in 2004, as head of the state board of higher education, tocco demanded that state colleges raise graduation rates. ticked off: state college presidents, who said tocco was not taking into account factors beyond their control. result: college graduation rates have increased from 43 percent to 49 percent in the past three years. incomplete in 2005, the state board of higher education, with tocco as its head, rolled out a financial-aid overhaul proposal. ticked off: legislators, who were not informed beforehand. result: tocco mollified legislators by meeting with them; plan remains a work in progress.

hl1: Neely banking on fair contract
lede: he has kept an eye on what has transpired this busy hockey offseason, but cam neely hasn't been distracted by any of it. as story upon story is written about this multimillion-dollar contract and that trade in a league that is clearly suffering growing pains, neely has gone about the business of getting some relaxing in before it's time to put on the uniform for his eighth professional season, his fifth as a boston bruin. he's not completely removed from the shifting tides in the market, however. he's in the middle of a long-term pact that pays him a base salary of $ 325,000 annually and has three years remaining, and bruins president/general manager harry sinden and neely's agent, mark perrone, are renegotiating the terms.
body: he has seen the money st. louis has lavished on winger brett hull and defenseman scott stevens and he has watched as sinden has tried to hammer out a renegotiation with defenseman raymond bourque. "there's no question the market has changed from what it used to be," said neely, relaxing in his living room. "when you see a team like st. louis paying that kind of money, you know there's money out there. whether there's that kind of money out there such as stevens' $ 5.1 million deal, we're not sure. a lot of us were waiting to see what was going to happen with brett hull, and it happened and i think it blew everyone away. i'm in a different situation than he was. he played out his option. i'm in the middle of a contract. guys can't really expect, unless they're in the situation that brett hull was in, to really get that kind of money, i don't think." neely said he doesn't think that what happens with bourque has anything to do with what happens with him. "i know what i want to get. i don't think it really matters with me what happens with ray other than the fact i want him to be happy and hopefully get what he's looking for," he said. "mark and i have sat down and talked about what i think i'm worth to the club, and, basically, i'm going on that." certainly, no one argues neely's importance to the bruins. last year he had 55 goals (the most by a bruin winger in a season) and 37 assists in 76 regular-season games while cutting his penalty minutes substantially. he added 12 goals in the playoffs and was a key reason the team went to the stanley cup finals. he played with discipline, knowing when to turn the other cheek, and his expectations for the 1990-91 bruins are high. ironically, neely said the most asked question of the summer is not about contracts but about the bruins' acquisition of tough guy chris nilan. "everyone has asked that," neely said. "i'm sure the fans will like him playing for the team. it depends on how he's going to play for us. throughout the course of the year, we did really well in not retaliating and not taking dumb penalties and our power play worked for us. i'm not saying that he's going to do that but to be aware that it worked for us. we've got to stick with, i think, the same plan." for neely, as the saying goes, the future's so bright he's got to wear shades. people forget he's only 25, but some of the things that a superstar might be interested in - namely, money - don't really concern neely. "people are surprised when i tell them my age. i've grown up a lot quicker than maybe some other people," he said. "i think a lot of it has to do with the way i was brought up. my family, we got what we needed and nothing more, and i think that's the way i approach my situation. i never really want people to think that i have this ego." part of his maturing process came as a result of personal tragedy. his mother died of cancer late in 1987, and neely played through the pain. that changed how he saw everything. "with my mom passing away, it certainly changed my views on life," he said. "my mom was concerned with the future, she was concerned with doing things so the family could be set for retirement, but retirement never came and i'm sure there were a lot of things my mom would've liked to have done. now i look at life like no one really knows what's going to happen tomorrow. if you have the opportunity to do something within your means, i think you should do it. "i'm lucky," he added. "i can't really complain.  i'm 25 years old and things are great."
